if u need this for debug purpose, add SSH key to users directive:
    users:

ironic_python_agent/hardware.py.message:
So should we completely fail cleaning if the device does not support format/secure erase?

I think my experience with operators would lean towards them wanting it to be an option *or* fall-through to disk wiping to maintain security.

My thinking is that if the device does not seem to support format/secure erase, _nvme_erase should fail and raise an "errors.BlockDeviceEraseError" exception so that it can be handled in erase_block_device (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ironic-python-agent/+/771904/24/ironic_python_agent/hardware.py#1302). Then, if shred fallback is enabled, the cleaning should continue in this way. If shred fallback is disabled, cleaning would indeed fail. 
My understanding is that's how the existing SATA Secure Erase codepath works - is this correct? (My intention was try make NVMe erase work consistently with SATA secure erase).  If not let's discuss further - will try to catch you on IRC.
I fully agree regarding giving the operators a mechanism to control shred fallback. I reused the same configuration option ([deploy]/continue_if_disk_secure_erase_fails) to control fallback to shred behaviour to allow the operators to control this.

Hey Marios, thanks for asking. 
The purpose of these ceph-ansible modules is basically avoid a bunch of shell/commands tasks against the ceph cluster, providing a lot of parameters in an unstructured way.
The module is supposed to make "atomic" an operation that is translated to a set of commands that can fail (for different reasons), and create lots of duplicated code for slightly different operations.
In addition, using a single module, CRUD operations on the ceph key object can be handled in a single place, making homogeneus the way we query the ceph cluster.
Regarding the upstream, these modules we're introducing here are not changing a lot over the time, they're supposed to deal with core components that preserve backward compatibility and we should start maintaining them for future release if new parameters are introduced (we're mostly talking about improvements, no changes are planned in the way the ceph api are consumed).
We can of course provide more information, but there are positive implications on using modules over a set of tasks to solve specific problems.

Hey Marios, in theory this feature is supposed to take (as an input) the whole spec file and apply it at bootstrap time. It's a different approach but I guess it's not much safer than the one we're adopting by default which is:

1. run cephadm on the first monitor and bootstrap a first, minimal, healthy cluster, made by mons and osds

2. for each component you want to add:
   a. build the spec section
   b. apply it

With the current implementation, which moves scenario001 (RBD) to cephadm, there are no bugs to point the users out, but it's something will be handled and/or (not) fully supported in a follow-up review, where multiple components (rgw, manila, ganesha, etc) are applied to the ceph cluster (scenario004).
For now (I mean for the current status of the role) I think it's enough, just don't want to see this XL review become bigger and bigger and hard to review.

        if not self._clone_v2_api_checked:

As the snat namespace is created during initialisation phase irrespective of snat gateway port bound on that host, as per the code this always falls under category SNAT rescheduled to different host [1].

We need sticky sessions when using Federation cause when the mod WSGI OIDC in apache2 starts the authentication process, redirecting the user to the IdP and then retrieving the token from IdP and redirecting the user back to the Apache2 WSGI to validate the token and state/nonce, if the IdP response is not handled by the same host that started the authentication process, an Invalid state error is raised by the WSGI in Apache2 as the host has not generated any state/nonce
Same as above, it should be `backend_http_extra`.

This part of making connections to keystone sticky is only required for external URLs as you can't get no-interactive connections from Openstack cli or sdk with oidc the way you could get it with ECP SAML2 (To my knowledge).

The only available scenario is if your internal network isn’t a vrf or a private non-routable network and so your admins/operators use that network to directly connect internally to the internal network the way services do it, which is a security concerns if not an issue.
I obviously meant for « internal » usage. Sorry for the mistake.

As stated upper on previous patchset, balance source is performing full sticky sessions, meaning that if your node is down your user won’t be able to authenticate as HAProxy will consider the cookie as invalidating the eventual redirect to the remaining node. Additionally if your customer IP change (lease expiration etc, which us highly probable for client side desktop/laptop/phone) the session won’t be valid anymore and you’ll have to login again.

It would be better to use roundrobin or leastconn with a session cookie, that would let HAProxy to appropriately let you contact the correct backend if the node you were connecting from died or if the lease of your client expired.

Additionally, there is an optional extra option that can be used to be more deterministic on the way HAproxy is handling the backend chosen for your session which is: hash-type that can be set to many options such as consistent / map-based / sdbm, etc (see haproxy doc about that).
We use consistent on our side but that could be something up to the operators to choose.
Good point! Yes it should be too.
We use balance source without session cookie for horizon. Should that be changed as well?

roles/upload-logs-base/library/zuul_swif.message: Using an empty string as a sentinel object it's unpythonic and ambiguous. It's common to default to `None` for this purpose.

I agree, let's change this to:

  proxy_address=None

as a default value.

It's typical to do checks like `if proxy_address is None` but the moment you start using magic values with unspecified meaning (an empty string, an arbitrary number etc) it makes the code hard to understand and reason about. One way to improve this is to declare a "constant" holding this value but having a helpful name, then any code using it would read better: `if proxy_address is UNSPECIFIED_DEFAULT_SENTINEL:` — a good name will always improve the maintainability of the code as well as its readability.

Also, a caller can easily break this by passing `None` and the next thing you know `container == 'None/some/path'` will cause all sorts for interesting side effects.

But in this case, you can probably get away with a much simpler pythonic idiom:
```
endpoint = proxy_address or self.cloud.object_store.get_endpoint()
```
(this means that if `proxy_address` is "falsy", then the fallback will be used and the `truthy` value from the arg will be used otherwise)

I also agree with this, the listed example of:

  endpoint = proxy_address or self.cloud.object_store.get_endpoint()

That looks much cleaner than this.

It is usually a good idea to add new args at the end of the function signature as it may break some calling code (especially if it's untested and/or external).

If somebody who was calling this function keeps their code and has explicit value for `dry_run` set to `True`, and it's passed as a positional argument, it may implicitly cause `proxy_address=True` while the unspecified `dry_run`'s value will become `False`. This sort of thing may be hard to debug.

P.S. If you consider this function a private API, it should have a leading underscore in the name (as in `_run()`) by convention.
I don't think this is a private/public API issue, but I agree that we should add it to the end.
I think you'll have to add proxy_address here too to the Ansible module options.

nit: use os.path.sep

I'm also surprised!  https://docs.python.org/3/library/os.path.html#os.path.split

But no one is gunna be trying to run any of this on windows anytime soon and we do a lot of rsplit('/') around here...
I should make better use of all the calls to os.path.* we've already got up above -- will take another stab.
ok, useful comment. and we don't want to rehash these until they have been cleaned

Yeah, in general we want to put off rehashing until everything's been cleaned up, since that's the point at which diskfiles are settled and we're getting ready for replication again. The trouble is that cleanup doesn't visit all partitions following an increase. (Though it *will* during a cancel!)

(I may be wrong...) this doesn't do a listdir, so if this is an existing partition that happened to be on same device then will relinked objects get hashed if they added a new suffix? I guess it wouldn't matter too much, now we're doing an invalidate_hash on relinking - it'll eventually be rehashed by replicator.

We can do better with this. Inspect the hashes returned to determine whether there's anything there; if not:

 acquire partition lock
 rm hashes.pkl hashes.invalid .lock
 release partition lock
 rmdir <partition>

(*Don't* use rmtree, in case something suddenly *does* turn up.)

I'd *love* it if the empty handoffs weren't even around once relinking's done.
Yup, relinked objects would get rehashed here since the relink (and its call to invalidate_hash) happened already.

it's a little tricky to keep track of this hook executing in two different contex

 - if we're in 'cleanup' do a rehash of *this* ("lower"?) partition
 - if we're in 'relink' but only if this is an "upper" part do a rehash of the ... target parts (!?)

So if we're going from 2^2 to 2^3 and find part 4 (i.e. a new upper part) then we hsah... 8 & 9 (those don't even exist in 2^3)

if part_power is 2, we'd acctually have "filtered" part 4 - besides this "upper" is the upper of the *old* part, in 2^2 that's 2 & 3 - which would reash 4&5, and 6&7 (which seem fine, 2&3 would get rehashed after cleanup)
this is a failry anemic config; it'd be nice to get in at least reclaim age.
Mirrored from existing code in cleanup, but you're right -- will fix.
was this a bug? i.e. if relinking into an existing partition the previously hashes were not invalidated; new partitions just don't have hashes.pkl yet
we could probably conslidate the calls to invalidate if we have multiple hashes in a suffix

Yeah, previously you could get bad/stale hash data shortly after relinking. Romain pointed out to me how the replicator would eventually get around to rehashing it [0]; this just deals with it more quickly. (The reconstructor apparently *always* rehashes [1], which feels like another bug.)

Consolidating calls seems a little tricky -- you'd want to do it on the *last* diskfile in the suffix in case there was some rougue process that got hashes midway through relinking, but we don't know when that happens.

I suppose you could accumulate the suffixes touched and invalidate all of them at the end of the partition -- but then, that's going to be all of them... so I guess we could just remove hashes.pkl before getting hashes... but then, what happens if the node unexpectedly restarts, or the process is otherwise interrupted? And are we OK with responding with bad/stale hashes mid-relink? This seemed safest; consolidate_hashes() is perfectly content to deal with duplicate entries.

[0] https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/2.26.0/swift/obj/replicator.py#L630-L632
[1] https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/2.26.0/swift/obj/reconstructor.py#L930-L931
more readable as dirname(dirname(fname)) - oh, i guess it follows the other invalidate signature

Again, love the ascii art. but just to understand this. The letters here are what, devices in the ring or partitions.

The devives in the ring after increase_part_power is [AABBCC] Ie device A is now responsible for partitions 0 and 1.

It's (roughly, kinda sorta) partitions in the old partition space. So A, B, C were partitions 0, 1, 2; after relinking, they've been mapped

 0 -> 0, 1
 1 -> 2, 3
 2 -> 4, 5

etc. Of course, nobody should really be using a part power of 4 outside of a dev env, so I suppose in practice A would really be more like the *block* of partitions 0-4096 or something, but you get the idea.

Not sure this makes sense. We only need to visit 2**part_power parts in the relinking phase to relink everything. We even make sure of that in the partition filter for relinking so how can the partition above ever be > 2**part_power?

I guess I can go confirm that by actaully testing. This comment was made by reading the code. Maybe my in brain python interpritor is broken (or I missed something obvous) which is definitely possible :P

It's comparing against 2**(part_power -1) -- i.e., we only come in here for the upper half of the old partition space. So this block is for the last part of the comment above; the

 and partition >= 2 ** (states['part_power'] - 1)

says partition is in that I-P range, so we go rehash the two *new* partitions that won't be checked during cleanup.
Oh yes!!! I just clicked, very cleaver! I see it now. For the last 1/2 of the lower value, you can shift into the upper value to rehash!

I was about to suggest this before but Mel has noted that we don't want the conductor or scheduler started here so this is fine.

a delete request ? Or are there other request types that could cause this to happen? The bug report suggests this is confined to deletes during a boot

As an aside, it's seems strange that we use a lock on the compute host when doing things like attaching volumes but not when deleting servers (maybe that's how you're fixing this, idk yet 😅)

> Re: locks, while we could lock the usual way here (in compute/api), it would only help us if the racing requests happened to land on the same API worker, so it would be limited in how much it helps. We'd need a distributed lock, and with that we'd also need to be able to "transfer" ownership of the held lock to another service (nova-conductor), as instance create happens across both nova-api and nova-conductor. (And delete happens across nova-api and nova-compute). It could be done, but it's a lot more involved than the usual locking we do today.

Aha, so we would. That makes sense. Thanks for the thorough clarification, both

Based on the code inspection I did, I believe delete request is the only way this code path can be hit. I worded it as "another request" in case there's any other way it could happen. The conductor deletes the build request as part of its usual work, but in the time I spent tracing the code, I couldn't find a way this path could happen if it was the conductor that deleted the build request. Disclaimer, I could have missed something, so I thought it was safest for me to write "another request" in case there's another way, as the conclusion I came to was based on code inspection by my eyeballs alone.

Note that this code path is *not* the one reported in the bug (that's the other test, test_deleting_instance_at_the_same_time). I added this test to add coverage for the other "if not instance:" case that could raise the AttributeError, here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/e7aa436dc6158a124529bb64b1d98e5c95596236/nova/compute/api.py#L2241-L2244

Re: locks, while we could lock the usual way here (in compute/api), it would only help us if the racing requests happened to land on the same API worker, so it would be limited in how much it helps. We'd need a distributed lock, and with that we'd also need to be able to "transfer" ownership of the held lock to another service (nova-conductor), as instance create happens across both nova-api and nova-conductor. (And delete happens across nova-api and nova-compute). It could be done, but it's a lot more involved than the usual locking we do today.

Delete request right?

doc/source/user/versioning_tutorial.rst.message: I thought this was no longer necessary. I'm not sure why, but iirc we have long since stopped updating parent versions when a child is updated

Thanks for clearing this up:

Yes, I understand that obj_relationships is to be used for "composition" only. I think at this point I had run a bit out of steam, so this explains the poor explanation.

I'll see if it's simple to rework the examples, but I'll definitely point out obj_relationships is something to be avoided and manifests are used in practice.

Yeah, I was wondering about that too. The trick is that the obj_relationships field _has_ to be updated. I'm not sure if that touched the object hash or not - one more thing to test and verify.

One more clarification: this is not a parent / child relationship that changed in this case, it's an owned / contained relationship.

Yeah, so obj_relationships is not for subclasses, but for nested objects stored inside an object (i.e. an Object field of a different type). _That_ behavior is no longer necessary because of the manifest stuff we have.

Now, there may be some accidental effects of the legacy obj_relationships stuff (which we had hoped to remove some day) that "helps" you here, if that's what you're implying, but it's entirely unintentional. I think it would be better to remove the obj_relationships mention from here (except for any case where you mention it's old and shouldn't be used for new code). If there's really a requirement for bumping the child class along with the parent, I think you just need to tell people to be careful and not imply or state that we have actual code to handle that.

OK, I think it turns out to be pretty important to version bump here _if_ you want to have deterministic serialization.

For example, you did not version bump Beta, Day 7 would serialize the 'physics_model' field to version 1.0 for Beta version 1.4. Day 8 would serialize the field to version 1.1. Version bumping the owner (or container) class is a guaranteed way to be absolutely certain that a Day 8 object creator can pass the object to a Day 7 consumer where the creator has absolute control about the fields and how the object is backleveled.
bikeshed: I kinda like reverse ordering here, since it looks like C unwinding.
bikeshed: the if/elif/else tree here makes diffs a little smaller, but only works if it's done in forward order.

I'm planning to add FAQ's here, like:
1. What are the guarantees: "The creator of an object using Day X code, can backlevel it to a version acceptable for a Day 1 to X consumer."
2. You don't have to follow this, but if you don't you might need to add logic to your consumers to accept future versions.

Also, in a follow-on, I plan to highlight the changed lines between each day.

Aren't role/scope two different concepts? I may be misunderstanding this column.

Correct - since we have an implication between the roles, we assume admins can do anything. It implies the highest level of authorization, which makes sense logically and for backwards compatibility.

The member role may have a subset of the permissions admin has. Reader has a subset of the member's permissions.

Correct. A role is a construct within keystone that is used in building role assignments. A scope is the authorization target. For example:

  $IDENTITY has the $ROLE role on $SCOPE

Could be substituted with:

  Jane has the member role on project foo

Which, we can classify as saying:

  Jane falls within the project member persona for project foo, or
  she is a project member of project foo

Part of the work we're doing is to break the automatic implication that 'admin' roles carry authorization to do most anything, simply because of the role name. By consuming scope, we can deliver nine different personas using three roles and three scopes as opposed to creating nine different roles:

* project_reader
* project_member
* project_admin 
* domain_reader (n/a for the time being)
* domain_member (n/a for the time being)
* domain_admin (n/a for the time being)
* system_reader
* system_member
* system_admin

Overloading role name with scope information is redundant since it's already built into the role assignment (even though this is typically how operators solved this problem before keystone supported system-scope). It can also be misleading if you mix the implied scope with the actual scope. For example, what should services do when a user has the project_member role on the system? What should they do if a user has the system_admin role on a project?

I'm only providing this as historical context to explain how and why we decided to build common personas from roles and scopes. In case it's helpful in building out this table.
Lance, are these things documented externally, where we can link to them in this spec? Specifically the keystone spec related to the addition of the idea of scope.

conceptually

Certainly something to keep in mind.

Keystone automatically implies a relationship between the three roles. The admin role implies member, and the member role implies reader. This establishes a hierarchy between the roles, which is a desirable feature in any RBAC-based system [0].

Since most OpenStack users have a member role on a project, and member implies reader, that means those users are going to inherit read-only permissions. This is typically straight-forward so long as the readable resource or API doesn't contain sensitive user-specific data. For example, we wouldn't want project readers to view secrets owned by other users simply because they have the reader role.

[0] https://csrc.nist.gov/CSRC/media/Publications/conference-paper/2000/07/26/the-nist-model-for-role-based-access-control-towards-a-unified-/documents/sandhu-ferraiolo-kuhn-00.pdf see section 2.2 on Hierarchical RBAC

Line 111-112 could be more clearly written as:

> scope-role combinations may be formatted as "{scope}-{role}". For example, the "admin" role in the "project" scope would be written as "project-admin".

I suggest consistently using the term "scope-role" and "scope/role" rather than "role-scope" or "role/scope", to match the ordering in the formatting convention.

Transposing the order of the formatting convention is also undesirable, because, for example, "admin-project" is ambiguous.

You might also consider a more qualified formatting convention like "{{scope},{role}) scope-role", to make it clear that we are talking about a tuple of two values of type scope-role.

This is totally up to the service. Keystone opted to keep all writable operations isolated to the 'admin' role. So, there isn't any difference between someone with the member role on the system and someone with the reader role on the system. They're effectively the same.

We decided this was the right security approach for keystone, by default. If operators decide to offload some administrative functions to system-members, they can supply the override and use the default member role, which still maintains the hierarchical relationship.

specs/approved/secure-rbac.rst.message: Revised, Thanks!

I think using both roles and a node's owner/lesseee at the same time may be a mistake. They both try and do the same thing - define a role - and they each solve a different use case, so combining the two may result in something strange.

Would the following work?

* define a PROJECT_ADMIN as someone matching owner_id and having the admin role
* defining a PROJECT_MEMBER as *one* of the following:
   * matching the owner_id and having the member role
   * matching the lessee_id

We default to one of the definitions of PROJECT_MEMBER,and include documentation explaining that each definition of PROJECT_MEMBER fits a separate use case, and explaining how to switch from one to the other.

specs/approved/secure-rbac.rst.message: Ultimately if nova can toggle a vif attachment using say a member account, it should be possible basically immediately as soon as system scope is implemented.

For my understanding, how do we handle this use case?

* Project A is the owner of Node 1; they have the `admin` role for project A
* Project B is the owner of Node 2; they have the `admin` role for project B
* Project A becomes the lessee of Node 2

What combination of permissions gives A Project-Admin access to Node 1, and Project-Member access to Node 2?

I'm going to make up some values here for the sake of an example.

Let's assume Alice is an administrator of Project A she should have owner rights on Node 1 and lessee rights on Node 2.

Let's also assume ironic has a policy, called `ironic:foo`, that protects an API intended for system users and baremetal owners. Ironic also has a policy, called `ironic:bar`, that protects an API that should be exposed to system users, baremetal owners, and lessees.

We could write policy checks in the following way:

  "ironic:foo": "(role:admin and system_scope:all) or (role:admin and project_id:%(owner)s)"

The above policy will:

* allow Alice to call the API protected by `ironic:foo` on Node 1 because her token is scoped to Project A, which is the owning project of Node 1
* prevent Alice from calling the API protected by `ironic:foo` on Node 2 because her token is scoped to Project A, which is the lessee of Node 2

We can write a policy for `ironic:bar` to expose functionality for Node 2:

  "ironic:bar": "(role:admin and system_scope:all) or (role:admin and project_id:%(owner)s) or (role:member and project_id:%(lessee)s))"

The above policy will:

* allow Alice to call the API protected by `ironic:bar` on Node 2 because her token is scoped to Project A, which is the lessee of Node 2
So this is going to be restricted to system users?

specs/approved/secure-rbac.rst.message:
Possibly, it is really noted as a risk and item that may require additional work.

In essence what happens today:

User foo in project banana: Hi nova, give me a ham sandwich, with neutron network kiwi and cinder volume tokyo.

Nova calls cinder and says: Hi cinder, I'm cinder with a request from user foo in the banana project. They want tokyo attached.

Cinder authenticates the request and *should* act for the user in the project.

Neutron essentially does the same thing. Or at least should. Cinder has a bit more strict schema, anyway that is an aside.

But the risk is more in that what if a service doesn't do these sorts of validations upfront. We don't really do it in ironic's case. We expect nova to have done pre-flight validation checking. Where this becomes problematic is when we have a stored vif or volume. We only pass-through context on the original acts/requests, but not on follow-up items. The risk for us is largely granting users access to vif plugigng or volume attachment without that validation. We might be in fairly good shape, but we need to be cognizant that something a little more may or likely will be needed.

So at the same time, because say if all services are changed to system admin or member tokens, instead of admin project tokens on behalf of other project still bearing the original user context, services like cinder/neutron may need additional checks or logic updated that we can only kind of maybe foresee on the outside as a possible risk until we get to that point of starting to switch everything over.

So in this context, the integrated or coupled projects are those that call ironic's APIs and those that call other project's APIs such as Ironic. We're all kind of in the same boat and just have to be careful to make sure we appropriately guard things we do with other services on behalf of the user request.

This is a great example/explanation. Is the spec too long if this is added? (Wondering if it could be added at the end of the spec in a misc section or something. Anyway, it is documented in this PR :)
